In our experience, COVID-19 wasn't a linear thing where you felt sick, and then started to feel better. It came in waves. We had bad symptoms the first 3-4 days, those symptoms went away in Days 5 and 6, but then returned around Day 7 or 8.

Even "mild" COVID-19 cases can be pretty scary, though. There was one day where it looked like we were going to have to go to the ER, and even now, our lung function isn't anywhere near normal. Even the very smallest exercise gets us winded.

Temperature checks made sense for SARS, because people weren't really contagious until they started showing symptoms. But there's growing evidence that COVID-19 is transmissible in asymptomatic or presymptomatic people. https://t.co/ltwMEimVdr

If you wait until there’s evidence of a COVID-19 outbreak, then, guess what, you have an outbreak! The point is to lock things down before that, and get test-and-trace in place before it’s everywhere.

In general, a blood oxygen level below 95 is cause for concern. The tricky thing in my case was that I would get some readings in the 80s or low 90s that would then get up to normal levels—96 to 98—within a minute or two. 

Check twice a day, or whenever you feel short of breath.

Important story about how covid-19 sneaks up on people:

I only had a mild case, but I had weeks of not-so-great to actually pretty bad blood oxygen readings—and that was when I wasn't even feeling short of breath! Everyone needs a pulse oximeter at home. https://t.co/nMGtYLmQ5I https://t.co/wU67LSui0L

One day when I felt particularly short of breath, my blood oxygen reading started out at 74, and then moved up to 97 within a few minutes. Another started out at 88. I also had readings that started at 95, and then *fell* to 82. This was three weeks after my symptoms began!

Staying hydrated is very important if you have COVID-19. We had lots of Gatorade. 

Having a pulse oximeter is a must. You're going to feel short of breath, and you need to be able to quantify how bad (or not) it is.

The point is that there's still a lot we don't know about COVID-19. I was briefly getting blood oxygen readings that suggested I should be in extreme distress even when I didn't feel like I was having much trouble breathing. Doctors don't seem to know what to make of this.

By Day 10, all of my symptoms were gone except occasional shortness of breath. But the strange thing is, if anything, my blood oxygen levels began to get worse. Maybe half the time, the readings would start out in the low 90s—95 and above is normal—and gradually move up.

If you can still find one, I highly recommend buying one of those fingertip oxygen testers. 

Being able to regularly check our oxygen levels has helped keep us sane when we were wondering how bad our shortness of breath was.

My wife has lost her appetite and her sense of taste. Both are slowly coming back. Neither of those have happened to me yet, although she got sick a few days before me.

We both experienced shortness of breath yesterday, but aren't feeling it as much now.
